comments.content: Traffic is entering FG on port 3 but isnt leaving it on port 1, so problem lies on fortigate. External sniffer is a bogus answer and gives you no information. Only correct option is a debug flow (or simply check logs) to see why traffic is failing

It is not confirmed if traffic is egressing port1, all we see in the flow debug is inbound traffic from the host on port3 that wants to go to the web server out port1. Personally, I would sniff the web host to see if they are getting in. But I feel the answer Fortinet is looking for is what myutran and bluey say it is; D. the flow debug will confirm the traffic inbound on port3 and if it is egressing port1. the flow debug will also show us if the web server traffic is even entering the FG or being denied. Sniffers do not show deny traffic, only debugs do that.

It is simple , if you see the filters it says interface any, so this means that if the packet is leaving the Fortigate, we would be able to see it, but we are not.
So this means the packet is getting drop in the Fortigate, so we need the debug.

discussion.content:
Debug flow will show why the Syn packet is not creating a new session
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.2.3/cookbook/054688/debugging-the-packet-flow

choices.A: Run a sniffer in the web server.
choices.B: Execute another sniffer in the FortiGate, this time with the filter "host 10.0.1.10".
choices.C: Capture the traffic using an external sniffer connected to port1.

discussion.content:
To add flexibility to your SSL-VPN deployment, you may consider configuring SSL-VPN realms.
The realms are custom login pages. They are usually for user groups, such as your accounting team and your
sales team, but can be for individual users as well. With realms, users and user groups can access different
portals based on the URL they enter. - A

choices.C: Two firewall policies with different captive portals.
choices.D: Different virtual SSL VPN IP addresses for each group.
choices.B: Two separate SSL VPNs in different interfaces mapping the same ssl.root.
choices.A: Different SSL VPN realms for each group.

questions.question_text:
A company needs to provide SSL VPN access to two user groups. The company also needs to display different welcome messages on the SSL VPN login screen for both user groups.
What is required in the SSL VPN configuration to meet these requirements?

choices.C: They require two firewall policies: one for each directions of traffic flow.
choices.A: They can be configured in both NAT/Route and transparent operation modes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about policy-based IPsec tunnels are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
D.
FortiGate Security 6.2 Study Guide, page 336
It's D :D the questions says the web server is a PRIVATE ca cert, so you won't have it on trusted CAs ;D
D, because fortinet will present similar (if trusted, then trusted, if untrsuted, then untrusted) cert to browser, what it sees on website.

D. 
FortiGate Security 6.0 Study Guide, P.304,

questions.question_text:
An employee connects to the https://example.com on the Internet using a web browser. The web server's certificate was signed by a private internal CA. The
FortiGate that is inspecting this traffic is configured for full SSL inspection.
This exhibit shows the configuration settings for the SSL/SSH inspection profile that is applied to the policy that is invoked in this instance. All other settings are set to defaults. No certificates have been imported into FortiGate. View the exhibit and answer the question that follows.
//IMG//

Which certificate is presented to the employee's web browser?

choices.B: The user's personal certificate signed by a private internal CA.

choices.D: It authenticates the traffic using the authentication scheme SCHEME1.
choices.A: It always authorizes the traffic without requiring authentication.
choices.C: It authenticates the traffic using the authentication scheme SCHEME2.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The answer is D.

Found this question also for preparing to NSE4 7.0. But answer "D" is not clear to me. 

"Authentication rules are used to receive user-identity, based on the values set for protocol and source address. Having said this, if a rule fails to match based on source address, there will be no other attempt to match the rule, however the next policy will be attempted. "
https://www.fortinetguru.com/2019/05/authentication-in-security-policies/

There is only "one" authentication rule, that does not match on 10.2.1.200. I can't see another rule that do match on 10.2.1.200. Schouldn't traffic be blocked in this case?
D is correct, not C cause 10.2.1.200 is part of 10.2.1.0/24 subnet, doesn't applies 10.0.1.0/24 subnet's rule
